dc:title: Marsh mat flotation in the Louisiana delta plain
dc:creator: Swarzenski C.
dc:description: On the Mississippi River delta plain, a freshwater marsh, dominated by Panicum hemitomon, floated directly with ambient water levels, provided they were high enough to float the mat. Water levels varied by c70 cm and mat movement by 55 cm. An intermediate-salinity marsh closer to the Gulf of Mexico and dominated by Sagittaria falcata moved 35 cm vertically during the study period, and water levels moved 70 cm. A brackish marsh, dominated by Spartina patens, moved only 3 cm in response to 40 cm of vertical water movement. The freshwater marsh floated throughout the year, provided ambient water levels were high enough, and mat movement followed water-level movement directly. The intermediate marsh exhibited seasonal buoyancy. In summer and early autumn, this marsh responded to water-level oscillations directly. It was the least buoyant in late winter. The shallow substrate of the two fresher marshes, which could respond directly to water levels, contained almost no mineral sediment (9% by dry weight at the fresh site and 17% at the intermediate), whereas the brackish marsh, which showed only small fluctuations relative to water movement, contained almost 50% mineral sediment by weight. The fresh marsh had the most fibric substrate in the upper 30 cm; the organic substrate material became progressively more decomposed with proximity to the Gulf of Mexico and with depth. -from Authors

dc:title: Growth and development of natural seedlings of Abies and Tsuga in old-growth forest
dc:creator: Zobel D.
dc:description: One- to six-year-old seedlings of Abies amabilis, Tsuga heterophylla and T. mertensiana were collected from 15-cm-deep volcanic tephra deposited beneath a surviving tree canopy during the 1980 eruption of Mount St Helens, Washington. Abies seedlings were heavier than Tsuga initially, with deeper and more-complex roots, but biomasses of Abies and Tsuga seedlings became more similar with time. Height above the cotyledons was similar in older seedlings of the two genera, but branching began earlier in Tsuga. Tsuga had a higher relative growth rate than Abies, with both greater leaf-biomass ratio and greater assimilation efficiency. Leaf allocation of Abies exceeded that of Tsuga at first, but eventually became less than that of Tsuga. Most measures of size decreased for Tsuga as canopy cover increased; for Abies, only the amount of root branching declined. As litter increased, root dimensions of both genera declined, but biomass of Tsuga increased whereas that of Abies decreased. Abies seemed less affected by both shade and limited soil moisture than Tsuga. -from Authors

dc:title: Biological Flora of the British Isles. Tilia cordata Miller (T. europaea L. pro parte, T. parvifolia Ehrh. ex Hoffm., T. sylvestris Desf., T. foemina folio minore Bauhin)
dc:creator: Pigott C.D.
dc:description: No 174 in the series reviews small-leaved lime, a deciduous tree widely but unevenly distributed in England and Wales. The paper describes the species and its variations across Europe and Asia, where it may be regarded as a collective species of at least seven species or subspecies, before discussing: geographical and altitudinal distribution: habitat, including its climatic and topographical limitations, preferred substrata, and influence on soil; communities, these being chiefly W8-W11, W16 and W17 in the UK National Vegetation Classification; response to biotic factors; gregariousness, performance in various habitats, effect of frost and drought, and response to atmospheric pollution; morphology, mycorrhiza, perennation and reproduction, chromosomes and physiological data; phenology; floral biology, hybrids, seed production and dispersal, and viability of seeds; animal feeders or parasites, divided into bird, mammal, and large collection of insect parasites, as well as plant parasites and diseases; and lastly the history of this species, especially linked to the disappearance of woodlands. -J.W.Cooper

dc:title: Positive plant interactions in tundra vegetation and the importance of shelter
dc:creator: Carlsson B.
dc:description: The hypothesis that positive plant interactions, arising from species aggregations, are important in harsh environments was tested on the sedge Carex bigelowii in the alpine/subarctic tundra of Swedish Lapland. Aggregations of low-growing species (<15 cm tall) were not well developed, but when C. bigelowii was growing in close proximity to Cassiope tetragona or Empetrum hermaphroditum, two evergreen dwarf shrubs, or in mats of the moss Racomitrium lanuginosum, increased leaf lengths and culm heights were recorded, compared with plants growing >2 cm away from the dwarf shrubs or outside the moss mat. The effect of the dwarf shrubs was interpreted as a result of above-ground shelter because shoot height, as well as number of shoots, also increased when plywood shelters were erected on the windward side of C. bigelowii. The effects of this above-ground shelter on shoot growth could result from increased snow cover, protection against strong desiccating winds early in the growing season, and a warmer micro-climate. An alternative explanation for the increased growth of C. bigelowii near other species is that their patchy distributions may be related to localized increased soil nutrient status. When fertilizer was added to C. bigelowii, there were significant increases in shoot height and number. The benefits to C. bigelowii when growing close to other species may be a combination of shelter effects and a patchy distribution of nutrients. -from Authors

dc:title: Shade as a cause of the association between the cactus Neobuxbaumia tetetzo and the nurse plant Mimosa luisana in the Tehuacan Valley, Mexico
dc:creator: Valiente-Banuet A.
dc:description: The establishment phase of Neobuxbaumia tetetzo, a giant columnar cactus, occurs mostly beneath the canopies of trees and shrubs which act as nurse plants. This pattern cannot be attributed to preferential seed dispersion, as Neobuxbaumia fruits open while still on the plant, dropping c1000 seeds fruit-1 randomly around the parent plant. Mimosa luisana is the most abundant shrub in the community. Seed germination was lowest in open spaces. In all treatments, exclusion from predators significantly increased seedling survival. Only shaded treatments had live individuals at the end of the experiment, 2 yr later. Results suggest that the nurse-plant effect between N. tetetzo and M. luisana is chiefly the result of differential survival in shaded microsites with less direct solar radiation, and consequently with lower daytime temperatures and lower evaporative demand. Field samplings were conducted in two Mexican deserts located outside the tropical belt: the Vizcaino Desert in Baja California and the Gran Desierto de Altar in Sonora. In these deserts direct solar radiation has a southern azimuth all year round. Five of six succulent species analysed showed a significant pattern of greater establishment on the shaded north sides of nurse plants. -from Authors

dc:title: Competition between mosses (Splachnaceae) in patchy habitats
dc:creator: Marino P.
dc:description: Tetraplodon angustatus, T. mnioides, Splachnum ampullaceum and S. luteum grow on the droppings of large mammals and have their spores dispersed by flies (Diptera). Each species produced more gametophytes when grown alone on droppings than when grown in mixture. The relative competitive abilities of species differed, at least in part by differences in growth rates. In dry habitats, Tetraplodon produced more gametophytes than Splachnum and often eliminated them; the reverse was true in wet habitats. Congeneric species had relatively symmetrical competitive abilities in the field and did not eliminate each other from droppings. While the influence of habitat on relative competitive ability may potentially explain the infrequency of co-occurrence of species of different genera on droppings, the relatively symmetrical competitive abilities of congeneric species suggests that their long-term regional coexistence probably results from mechanisms that operate at larger spatial scales, such as large-scale fluctuations in the abundance and distribution of droppings in space and time, differential spore dispersal and the independent aggregation of spores of different species on droppings. (See also 92L/09966). -from Author

dc:title: The effects of successional habitat variation and time of flowering on seed production in Rumex acetosella
dc:creator: Escarre J.
dc:description: Rumex acetosella was studied in a successional series of abandoned fields near Paris, France. Overall, a decrease in filled-seed production per plant was observed with increasing successional age, but only for the early summer period. A similar trend was observed for reproductive effort, ie filled-seed production per unit of vegetative biomass. There were significant differences between the populations in the mean weight of filled seeds, but only for two of five monthly surveys. The successionally intermediate and advanced populations at one of the sites showed the greatest seed biomass. There were no significant negative correlations between number and biomass of seeds when all the populations were pooled, but seed mass was negatively correlated with seed number at four sites in June. Results indicate that genetically based differences in sexual resource allocation occur among plants growing along a successional habitat gradient. -from Authors

dc:title: A diffusion model for dispersal of Opuntia imbricata (cholla) on rangeland
dc:creator: Allen L.
dc:description: Overgrazing creates gaps or open spaces for cholla seeds or stems that fall to the ground to become established (passive dispersal). Also livestock or wildlife may cause stems and fruits to fall to the ground (active dispersal). A theoretical model is formulated for the dispersal of plants based on the diffusion equation which assumes one or more mechanisms of dispersal. Passive dispersal alone cannot account for the current spread of cholla on some of the pastures. -from Authors

dc:title: Dispersal and coexistence of mosses (Splachnaceae) in patchy habitats
dc:creator: Marino P.
dc:description: Examined three mechanisms that may promote coexistence of Tetraplodon angustatus, T. mnioides, Splachnum ampullaceum and S. luteum: differences between dry and wet habitats; seasonal segregation of resources, and interspecific dispersal differences. These mosses grow on the droppings of large mammals and have their spores dispersed by flies (Diptera). Droppings located in dry habitats were primarily occupied by Tetraplodon spp., droppings in wet habitats by Splachnum spp. In dry habitats there was a seasonal segregation of dropping colonization by Tetraplodon spp. Dung placed into the field in May, when sporophytes of T. angustatus matured, were exclusively colonized by T. angustatus; dung placed into the field in June, when most T. mnioides sporophytes matured, were primarily colonized by T. mnioides. Each species of moss attracted 10-17 species of spore-carrying flies; the fly faunas attracted to each species were 77-92% different from each other in species composition. Neither species of Tetraplodon appeared to have a clear dispersal advantage; for both, spore-carrying flies were predominantly associated with dung in dry habitats; spore-carrying flies captured on T. angustatus carried significantly more spores on average than did spore-carrying flies captured on T. mnioides; however, more flies captured on T. mnioides were carrying spores than were flies captured on T. angustatus. Although more flies captured on Splachnum luteum than on S. ampullaceum, were carrying spores, S. ampullaceum (the weaker competitior) appears to have more of its spores dispersed to dung in wet habitats that does S. luteum. Spore-carrying flies captured on S. ampullaceum and associated dung carried significantly more spores on average than did spore-carrying flies captured on S. luteum, and a much greater proportion of spore-carrying flies associated with S. ampullaceum than with S. luteum were also associated with dung in wet habitats. (See also 92L/10088). -Author

dc:title: Biological Flora of the British Isles. Avenula (Dumort.) Dumort.
dc:creator: Dixon J.M.
dc:description: No. 173 in the series reviews the two British species of this genus of oat-grasses, meadow oat Avenula pratensis and hairy oat A. pubescens, both of which grow on chalky soils, the latter being more abundant and widespread. Each half of the paper describes the plant itself, including subspecies, before discussing: geographical and altitudinal distribution; habitat; communities (with tables of species of calcareous grassland, communities in which the species occurs in continental Europe, and further associated species); response to biotic species; gregariousness, performance in various habitats, and effect of frost and drought; morphology, mycorrhiza, reproduction, chromosomes, and physiological data; phenology, floral biology, seed production and dispersal, and germination; animal feeders, parasites and diseases, and history. -J.W.Cooper

dc:title: Effects of leaf and ramet removal on growth and reproduction of Geonoma congesta, a clonal understorey palm
dc:creator: Chazdon R.
dc:description: In a Costa Rican rain forest (La Selva) 15 Geonoma congesta clones, each with eight or fewer stems, were assigned to each of four treatments: 1) control (no manipulation), 2) removal of all but one ramet, 3) removal of 50% of the leaves from one ramet, and 4) removal of all but one ramet plus removal of 50% of the leaves. Ramet and leaf removal alone did not significantly increase mortality over controls, but mortality was significantly increased when both ramets and leaves were removed. Leaf and ramet removal had no significant effect on height-growth and stem-growth increments. Leaf size and stem diameter after 3 yr were not influenced by leaf removal or ramet removal. Defoliated ramets had a significantly higher annual rate of leaf production per initial number of leaves than non-defoliated ramets, whereas ramet removal showed no significant effect on leaf production of the remaining ramet. Clones were remarkably resistant to repeated defoliation and ramet removal. Results suggest that stored reserves are mobilized to maintain normal patterns of growth and ramet production following defoliation. Clonal growth in this species appears to buffer individual ramets against traumatic effects of ramet and leaf removal on growth, survival and reproduction. -from Author

dc:title: Responses of Mediterranean grassland species to changing rainfall
dc:creator: Figueroa M.
dc:description: Changes over 14 yr were investigated in the composition of a species-rich grassland in SW Spain. The vegetation was dominated by winter annuals, which germinated after the autumn rains and fruited in late spring or early summer; they comprised 86 of the 99 species recorded. Most of these species displayed considerable variations in abundance over the period of study. The abundance of many species was highly correlated with rainfall, which accounted for up to 83% of year-to-year variance (in Juncus capitatus). Rainfall over the whole growing season was a good predictor of abundance for more species than any of its component periods (25 species with significant associations out of 99). Cluster analysis resolved five groups of species with similar year-to-year variations in abundance: two groups contained most of the species showing significant positive correlations with rainfall, and another group contained a small number of generally infrequent species that showed significant negative correlations. The species in the remaining two groups had few significant correlations with rainfall. Only three moderately abundant species were significantly correlated with time. -from Authors

dc:title: Growth patterns of tree height and stem diameter in populations of Abies veitchii, A. mariesii and Betula ermanii
dc:creator: Hara T.
dc:description: Small, suppressed individuals of Abies spp. showed little growth in tree height but grew in stem diameter. In small, suppressed individuals of B. ermanii, the converse was found. Stem diameter growth of Abies spp. and tree height growth of B. ermanii are affected only a little by competition between individuals even under crowded conditions, and thus growth in these dimensions is determined in a genetically strict manner for each species. These growth patterns correspond to the life-history traits and the successional status of Abies spp. (shade-tolerant late-successional species) and B. ermanii (a shade-intolerant early-successional species). -from Authors

dc:title: Competition and the coexistence of species in a mixed podocarp stand
dc:creator: Duncan R.
dc:description: Examined the importance of intra- and interspecific competition in affecting the growth and survival of Dacrycarpus dacrydioides and Dacrydium cupressinum, the two dominant trees in a mixed podocarp stand in Ohinemaka Forest, Westland, New Zealand. Two lines of evidence (spatial patterning of trees and correlates of tree performance with neighbourhood density) were used to infer the importance of competition. Intraspecific competition among D. dacrydioides trees appeared to be intense. Mean radial growth rate (MGR) was significantly negatively correlated with the number of conspecific neighbours, and patterns of non-random mortality resulted in a shift in spatial pattern from a significantly clumped to a significantly regular distribution. Intraspecific competition among D. cupressinum was less intense. D. cupressinum had a low rate of mortality, predominantly random spatial patterns of mortality, and a weak correlation between MGR and the number of conspecific neighbours. Differences in the relative importance of intraspecific competition in affecting survival and growth of the two species was attributed to differences in the distribution and availability of suitable establishment sites. D. dacrydioides preferentially established on abundant level or slightly elevated sites, and in patches reached densities where resources were limiting. The number and distribution of D. cupressinum were determined primarily by the availability of suitable elevated establishment sites that were scattered throughout the stand. The restricted number of suitable sites limited D. cupressinum to densities where resources were not severely limiting. The two species avoided interspecific competition by partitioning the variability in forest-floor micro-relief. -from Author

dc:title: New site formation and colonizing vegetation in primary succession on the western Amazon floodplains
dc:creator: Kalliola R.
dc:description: Newly deposited fluvial sediments are poor in organic C and N. Colonization begins either with immigrant propagules dispersed by wind or water, or with invasion of species by vegetative means. Usually numbers of individuals are few, and the initial vegetation pattern is a reflection of the small-scale mosaic of microsites. The pioneer flora (125 species recorded) includes many widespread perennial herbs; seeds of most forest species do not germinate in the dry sediments. Herbaceous colonist species are almost non-existent in suspension-poor rivers of low erosion rate. The persistence of the initial plant assemblage is controlled by the evolution of fluvial landforms. Only a few species among the set of colonists are significant in later forest succession. These include Tessaria integrifolia and Gynerium sagittatum, which resist moderate flood damage and resprout after burial. Mature seed populations of these 10-15-m-tall species are abundant at the outermost margin of the successional forest just beyond the fluvial bars. The low representation of tree species in the colonizing phase suggests that the extreme environmental conditions at the river margins differ from other natural environments along the Amazon. Aquatic succession on lakes affected by suspension-rich waters starts with genuine floating species. The general habits of these vegetation assemblages and their species composition are highly similar in the white-water floodplains of the Peruvian Amazon study area. An annual vegetation flush characteristically follows the flood period. Macrophyte vegetation is almost non-existent on the floodplain lakes of suspension-poor rivers. -from Authors

dc:title: The effect of reproduction on canopy structure, allocation and growth in Oenothera biennis
dc:creator: Reekie E.
dc:description: Regardless of age, reproduction increased stem allocation and decreased root and leaf allocation. Early reproduction reduced growth relative to vegetative plants, while late reproduction had no effect on growth in the long term and enhanced growth in the short term. Seed output increased with age at reproduction up to a point after which there was little change. The reduced growth of plants reproducing at an early age was due to a decrease in leaf area ratio, and the enhanced growth of older plants to a temporary increase. Specific leaf area in older plants increased with reproduction, temporarily over-compensating for the decrease in leaf allocation. There was a temporary increase in unit leaf rate in plants reproducing at a young age but not in plants reproducing at a late age. Changes in specific leaf area were the result of a switch in leaf morphology between vegetative and reproductive plants. Vegetative plants produced leaves with petioles which increased in length with age. This morphology minimized shelf-shading in the vegetative rosettes. Leaves produced after reproduction had short petioles and, consequently, a higher specific leaf area. Plants reproducing at an early age produced few new leaves and exhibited little change in specific leaf area. The beneficial effects of reproduction on canopy structure and photosynthesis that are observed in many species can compensate for the cost of reproduction, providing the accumulated nutrient reserves are sufficient to supply the reproductive structures. -from Authors

dc:title: Self-thinning and competition intensity over a gradient of nutrient availability
dc:creator: Morris E.
dc:description: High-density populations of Ocimum basilicum at each of three nutrient levels showed self-thinning with different biomass-density relationships (thinning lines) for each level. Competition at common plant mass was more intense in stands grown at low nutrient levels, but because thinning proceeded fastest in the stands grown at high nutrient supply, competition at a common time was most intense in these stands. The mechanism underlying intensified competition (irrespective of rate of development) is possibly the extent of overlap of resource depletion zones to achieve given plant mass. If this overlap increases at lower resource levels to achieve a given plant mass, competition will intensify at the lower resource levels, but the rate at which overlap develops at each resource level will determine the intensity of competition when stands are compared in time. Plants from stands grown at lower nutrient levels tended to have less radial extension of the canopy for a given height, and to be shorter and have less radial extension for a given shoot weight. Thus they packed their shoot weight into a smaller canopy volume plant-1 than plants at high nutrient levels. If canopy packing had determined the relative positions of thinning lines, populations grown at low nutrient levels would have followed higher thinning lines than those at high levels. Biomass packing measured at the population level showed the reverse trend, ie it was lower in the stands at low nutrient levels. This occurred because of the wider spacing between plants in these stands than in the high-resource stands at a given biomass level. Canopy interactions between plants grown at low nutrient levels were less than in plants grown at high nutrient levels. Thus the major determinant of plant spacing in the stands at low nutrient levels was below rather than above ground. Plants at the two lower nutrient levels grew relatively more root (weight and length) than those at the high nutrient level. Just under half of this root growth occurred in the top 16% of the soil volume. Root densities achieved were so high that conditions for mutual overlap of depletion zones for mobile nutrients were present. This is taken as evidence that increased overlap of nutrient uptake zones occurred at lower nutrient levels in order for plants to achieve a given mass. -from Authors

dc:title: Competitive effect and response: hierarchies and correlated traits in the early stages of competition
dc:creator: Goldberg D.
dc:description: Five weeks after sowing, significant non-linear regressions of target biomass on neighbour density were found for 59% of the 49 species combinations and significant linear regressions on neighbour biomass were found for 51% of the species combinations. The slopes of these regressions represent per-plant and per-gram competition coefficients, respectively. Neighbour species differed strongly in competitive effect per plant. Differences in effect per gram, response per plant, and response per gram were much weaker. Nevertheless, consistent competitive hierarchies were found for both effect and response on both a per-plant and per-gram basis. Neighbour species with larger seed mass and larger maximum potential mass had stronger per-plant competitive effects, whilst neighbour species with higher maximum relative growth rates had stronger per-gram competitive effects. The reverse of this latter pattern was seen for competitive response: target species with lower maximum relative growth rates were better response competitors. -from Authors

dc:title: Dynamics of soil-stored seed banks of six shrubs in fire-prone dune fynbos
dc:creator: Pierce S.
dc:description: Soil-stored seed banks of six non-sprouting dominant shrubs with small seeds (0.4-4.6 mg) were determined in three mature (13-yr-old) dune fynbos communities each autumn for three successive years. Instead of the large seed banks typical of shrubs from fire-prone vegetation, dune fynbos shrubs had relatively small seed banks: highest mean seed density recorded was 825 ± 1187 seed m-2. Shrub and community seed banks showed no significant increments over 3 yr. After a fire, seed banks were depleted by more than half. Removal of seeds by ants and rodents from the soil surface was relatively rapid. Almost all seed had been removed from open deposits by the sixth day of cafeteria experiments. Removal rates by ants of elaiosome-bearing (myrmecochorous) seeds was not significantly different from non-myrmecochorous species; neither were the intact seeds of a myrmecochorous species removed faster than the seeds from which the elaiosome had been removed. Seeds are thus removed by ants as much for granivory as for myrmecochory. Seed burials showed that seed bank losses due to decay and germination varied widely amongst species and with seed age, with losses ranging from 12-93%. There were large differences in seed-bank sizes between the six species which could be attributed to their life-history attributes such as seed production, dispersal mode and germination requirements. The myrmecochorous species with relatively large and poorly dispersed seeds, small to moderate seed production and seed-bank sizes, and germination and seedling establishment cued to post-fire conditions, were most vulnerable to local extinction. -from Authors

dc:title: Performance of two contrasting morphs of Brachypodium sylvaticum transplanted into shaded and unshaded sites
dc:creator: Davies M.S.
dc:description: Two contrasting morphs of slender false-brome Brachypodium sylvaticum which can be distinguished by the presence or absence of spreading macro-hairs at the leaf margins, termed hairy-edge (HE) and non-hairy-edge (NHE), are described. The NHE morph is confined to shaded sites, whereas the HE morph is found in both open and shaded habitats but is generally the less-frequent morph in shaded conditions. At a woodland site 77% of NHE transplants survived to 27 months compared with 45% of the HE plants. At the unshaded site, 90% of HE plants survived to 27 months compared with 60% of the NHE plants. The NHE morph grew better at the shaded site whilst the HE morph grew better at the unshaded site. The NHE morph allocated a greater proportion of the above-ground dry matter to reproductive tillers than the HE morph at both sites. The relative fitness of the "alien' morph declined with time for survival and tiller number and was also low for characters measured at the final harvest. -from Authors

dc:title: Riparian vegetation along current-exposure gradients in floodplain wetlands of the River Murray, Australia
dc:creator: Roberts J.
dc:description: On the Chowilla floodplain in the semi-arid zone of South Australia, four vegetation types were distinguished by cluster analysis and by separation of three ordination axes. The 1st ordination axis was a current-related gradient, having a significant regression on current; the vegetation type with the swiftest currents and steepest banks was riparian grasses. The third axis was a gradient related to exposure to wave action. -from Authors

dc:title: Colonization dynamics of herbs and shrubs in a disturbed northern hardwood forest
dc:creator: Hughes J.
dc:description: Following canopy removal at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire, the most common shrubs were Rubus idaeus and Viburnum alnifolium; the most common herbs were Aster acuminatus, Dennstaedtia punctilobula and Dryopteris spinulosa. All of the first-year recruitment of Rubus occurred through germination of buried seeds. First-year recruitment of the other four species occurred through survival of pre-existing stems or expansion of pre-existing patches, or both. Recruitment of Viburnum, Dennstaedtia and Dryopteris during the second and third years of regrowth continued to be strictly vegetative, whilst recruitment of Aster occurred through newly dispersed seeds as well as rhizomatous growth. The spatial distribution of herbs and shrubs after overstorey removal was strongly related to the location of predecessors before removal. Seed production in the site with overstorey removal was higher than in the surrounding, intact forest for most species. Some unoccupied sites were colonized by these seeds during the second and third years of regrowth. Ruderals obscured but did not affect spatial patterns of stress-tolerators and competitors that were present in the forest before overstorey removal. This suggests that, in the absence of physical destruction to existing herbs and shrubs in the forest, "disturbance' has, in the short term at least, little effect on spatial patterns of some understorey species. -from Authors

dc:title: A simulation of landscape-level stand dynamics in the northern hardwood region
dc:creator: Frelich L.
dc:description: The STORM simulation was developed to predict the response of regional stand age structure to a given disturbance regime. The outcome of STORM depends upon rotation periods of canopy disturbance, diameter growth rates of trees, and the relative susceptibility of pole, mature and large trees to windthrow. The simulation was run using data on disturbance frequencies from remnants of primary forest in western Upper Michigan. Rotation periods ranged from 69 yr for >10% canopy removal to 3734 yr for >70% canopy removal. Stands were classified into eight structural types, ranging from even-aged sapling stands to steady-state stands, which reflect the state of recovery from recent disturbances. The model suggests that most (87.4%) stands in the primeval hardwood forest were multi-aged, with several major and many minor age classes. Quasi-even-aged stands resulting from catastrophic disturbance occupied 9.2% of the landscape, and steady-state stands about 3.6%. The low frequency of steady-state stands on the landscape appears to be determined primarily by the high frequency of disturbances removing part of the canopy, rather than the interval between catastrophes. Changes in disturbance rates result in disproportionately large changes in the proportion of even-aged stands on the landscape, while mean canopy residence time for trees shows a damped effect. -Authors

dc:title: Genetic differentiation between populations of Plantago lanceolata. II. Phenotypic selection in a transplant experiment in three contrasting habitats
dc:creator: Van Tienderen P.H.
dc:description: Components of seed yield of transplants were correlated with the height of the surrounding vegetation. In pasture, plants produced far more seeds in tall vegetation, probably due to a low local grazing intensity. In early-mown hayfield tall vegetation was associated with a lower lifetime seed yield. At all sites, tall vegetation coincided with a low survival of transplants. In early-mown hayfield selection on timing of flowering and growth habit was found. At all sites seed production varied above all because of differences in plant size, and no further direct effects of phenotypic traits on seed yield could be detected. A trade-off between vegetative growth and reproduction is suggested. -from Authors

dc:title: Habitat and host preferences of Ficus crassiuscula, a neotropical strangling fig of the lower-montane rain forest
dc:creator: Daniels J.
dc:description: In the windy upper regions of the Cordillera de Tilaran, Costa Rica, F. crassiuscula is a common canopy tree restricted to tall lower-montane rain forest in sheltered ravine bottoms and lee slopes. F. crassiuscula has an unusual juvenile growth form, in which seedlings develop into viny saplings, rooting freely at the nodes and lacking apical dominance. This juvenile growth form can develop into sprawling thickets up to 5 m across. F. crassiuscula are four times as abundant on Guarea tuisana, three times as abundant on stumps, twice as abundant on Sapium pachystachys, and 1/5 as abundant on Ocotea spp. and on a Conostegia sp. as their relative stem densities would suggest. They are 3-5 times as abundant on Guarea spp., and half as abundant on Persea schiedeana and Ocotea spp. as expected from the host species contribution to the total forest trunk surface area. Dispersal and early establishment of F. crassiuscula are not critical determinants of host preference. The critical stage in determining the pattern of host preference seems to involve the morphological transition from viny sapling to juvenile with an erect stem, as juveniles are four times more abundant on Guarea spp. than their relative trunk surface area would suggest. The rate of viny saplings depends not only on host species, but also on how high above the ground they are established, and the locations they occupy upon their hosts. -from Authors

dc:title: Inverse salinity gradients in coastal marshes and the death of stands of Salix: the effects of grubbing by geese
dc:creator: Iacobelli A.
dc:description: Formation of large "peat barrens' (>100 m × 100 m) produced as a result of grubbing (removal of roots and rhizomes of ground vegetation) by lesser snow geese Chen caerulescens caerulescens in the spring was investigated in a low Salix community inland from the intertidal zone at La Perouse Bay, Manitoba. Within the snow-free season, experimental removal of the insulating mat of plant litter and ground vegetation resulted in increased temperatures of soils close to the surface, increased thermal gradients in soils and a substantial increase in the salinity (≤120 g of dissolved solids litre-1) of expressed water from the overlying, shallow organic layer (salinity of tidal water was <4 g l-1). The inverse salinity gradient from land to sea appears to be the result of grubbing. Premature leaf fall occurred from side shoots of Salix beneath which the graminoid sward had been artificially grubbed, but not from undisturbed Salix. Early leaf death was correlated with high foliar concentrations of sodium and chloride ions. Salix from artificially grubbed areas failed to develop leaves the following season and 24 months after removal of turf plants were dead. Spring grubbing initiates a series of environmental changes which make it unlikely that the original plant communities will reestablish in the foreseeable future (<15 yr). -from Authors

dc:title: Photosynthesis and successional status of seedlings in a tropical semi-deciduous rain forest in Nigeria
dc:creator: Riddoch I.
dc:description: Tests the hypothesis that photosynthetic performance of seedlings in a tropical forest depends on the successional status of the species, whereby pioneers should display an enhanced capacity to utilize the high photon flux density associated with a gap. Data were collected from species representing weeds of gaps (Chromoleana odoratum, Piper umbellatum), pioneer trees (Ceiba pentandra, Pterygota macrocarpa, Milicia excelsa, Ricinodendron heudelotii, Sterculia rhinopetula), and climax trees (Blighia sapida, Strombosia pustulata). Pioneer trees had photosynthetic attributes similar to weeds. Compared to climax trees, both groups had higher stomatal conductances, higher light compensation points, higher rates of dark respiration, much higher mesophyll conductances, and often higher quantum efficiencies. In a fluctuating light regime, there was no support for the hypothesis that species growing in shade show rapid stomatal responses to sunflecks; all species showed fluctuating rates of photosynthesis with little or no adjustment of stomata during the 20-min test. -from Authors

dc:title: Seed shadows generated by frugivorous birds in an eastern Mediterranean scrub
dc:creator: Izhaki I.
dc:description: Fruits of the five common fleshy-fruit plant species in an Israeli Mediterranean scrub were removed by twelve bird species of which seven were transients. Fruits of shrubs Rhamnus palaestinus and Pistacia lentiscus were removed mainly by all-year residents, while fruits of a semi-parasitic dwarf shrub Osyris alba, a vine Rubia tenuifolia and a tree P. palaestina were removed mainly by transients. Rhamnus was visited by most bird species more often than expected from its relative abundance, and the highest density of bird-deposited seeds was found under Rhamnus. Scrub clearings were largely avoided by birds. Fruits of the two shrub species were deposited under conspecific adults more often, but reached a greater diversity of habitat types, than the semi-parasitic shrub and the vine, which depended closely on other plants. Fruits of the semi-parasite and the vine may reach few but high-quality deposition sites, whereas those of bushes and trees reach wider variety of habitat types. No relation was found between body size, taxonomic affinity or status of a bird species, and its dispersing efficiency. As no plant species is more successfully dispersed than another, but a trade-off may exist in dispersal attributes, there is also no "ideal' disperser bird species. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of the strandline annuals Cakile maritima and Salsola kali. II. The role of nitrogen in controlling plant performance
dc:creator: Pakeman R.
dc:description: In strandline habitats, plants are large and fecund and on foredunes they are small and stunted. Addition of N caused a substantial increase in growth on the foredune, confirming its limited availability. Phosphorus was present in the foredune sand in sufficient quantity to support the extra growth of N-fertilized plants. Nitrogen addition increased the net photosynthetic rate of foredune plants to values comparable with those of unfertilized strandline plants. Nitrogen deficiency may limit growth on the foredune by restricting the rate of net photosynthesis. The differences in photosynthetic rate in the field could be attributed wholly to differences in leaf N status. (See also 92L/01537). -from Authors

dc:title: Pollination by a guild of fluctuating moth populations: option for unspecialization in Silene vulgaris
dc:creator: Pettersson M.
dc:description: Experimental pollination showed that c150 pollen grains per flower were required to achieve the average natural full seed-set in the plant population. Although 57% of the flower-visiting moths deposited pollen, only c10% of the moth visits delivered ≥150 pollen grains in one visit to virgin female flowers, indicating that seed-set usually originated from multiple pollinator visits. Pollen receipt indicated pollination by a guild of noctuid and sphingid moths. The abundance of the dominating pollinator species varied strongly between years. Most species deposited about the same mean number of pollen grains, although they were taxonomically diverse and had different flower-visiting behaviours and proboscis lengths. Even noctuid moths of the genus Hadena, known as associated larval seed predators of S. vulgaris, were not especially frequent or efficient pollinators despite the fact that these moths influence their larval food resource through pollination. -from Author

dc:title: Minimum light requirements of submerged freshwater macrophytes in laboratory growth experiments
dc:creator: Sand-Jensen K.
dc:description: Relative growth rates (μ) of macrophytes were measured in the laboratory at photon flux densities (PFD) between 0 and 105 μmol m-2s-1 at 7°C. Mean rates of carbon loss were low in plants kept in the dark (5.9 mmol C mol-1 cell C day-1) and corresponded to experimental dark respiration rates. Mean dark respiration with only 7.0 mmol C mol-1 cell C day-1 at the light compensation point (Ic), which was on average 6.9 μmol m-2s-1. Light compensation points and respiration rates were variable within species collected at different times and approached the variability among species. The growth efficiency in low light (the slope of μ vs. PFD) varied less within species and showed diffferences among species which were positively related to the maximum growth rate at high light. Overall, macrophyte species with different depth distribution or taxonomy did not differ systematically in dark respiration and growth performance in low light in the experiments. Experimental Ic levels of two charophyte species, converted to annual means (78-165 mol m-2 yr-1), corresponded to annual PFD levels of 40-200 mol m-2 yr-1 at the depth limit of charophyte species in the hypolimnion of oligotrophic temperate lakes. Experimental Ic levels of normally rooted angiosperms were much lower than PFD levels at their depth limits in epilimnetic waters. However, these plants formed no roots at low light in the laboratory and needed 24 μmol m-2s-1 for proper root development. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology and genetics of fitness in forest plants. III. Environmental variance in natural populations of Impatiens pallida
dc:creator: Bell G.
dc:description: Sets of families of the annual herb Impatiens pallida were created by crossing random individuals from a natural population growing in an undisturbed Fagus grandifolia-Acer saccharum forest near Montreal, Quebec. Replicate samples of these families were then planted into random sites in the same area from which the parents had been collected. Survival, growth and fecundity were scored in two experiments, conducted in similar habitats but in different locations and years. Various measures of all three variables were positively correlated with seed size; large seeds sometimes gave rise to large and fecund plants but small seeds never did. The fitness of most individuals was zero; a very small minority was highly fecund, and contributed most of the seed producted by the population. Survival growth and fecundity varied between sites within a 50 × 50 m area: there is substantial environmental variance at very small spatial scales in undisturbed natural environments. The environment is structured at very small spatial scales. Nearby sites at scales of 1-10 m were positively correlated both because of trends extending over the study area as a whole and because of much smaller-scale trends causing local patchiness. (See also 92L/07956 and 08004). -from Authors

dc:title: Succession from heather moorland to birch woodland. II. Growth and competition between Vaccinium myrtillus, Deschampsia flexuosa and Agrostis capillaris
dc:creator: Hester A.J.
dc:description: Vaccinium myrtillus, Deschampsia flexuosa and Agrostis capillaris are often successive dominants during succession from heather moorland to mature birch Betula woodland. At Glenlivet (Grampian) and Speyside (Highland Region), Scotland, all species showed reduced growth when shaded: V. myrtillus was least affected. Both D. flexuosa and A. capillaris showed strong positive growth responses to fertilizer addition, particularly in increased light. Vaccinium myrtillus showed a limited positive response. Agrostis capillaris showed consistent competitive dominance over D. flexuosa, which showed consistent competitive dominance over V. myrtillus. The timing of establishment of these species may be particularly important in determining their role in the succession from heather moorland to mature birch woodland. -from Authors

dc:title: Multiple controls of cliff-edge distribution patterns of Thuja occidentalis and Acer saccharum at the stage of seedling recruitment
dc:creator: Bartlett R.
dc:description: Along the Niagara Escarpment in Ontario, a stunted forest of old-growth Thuja occidentalis occurs on cliff faces, but is replaced by a deciduous forest dominated by Acer saccharum within 5 m of the cliff edge on the upper plateau. The stem frequencies of all seedling and sapling size-classes of Thuja decreased with distance from the cliff, but for Acer the smallest size classes displayed the greatest increase in stem frequency away from the cliff edge. Seed emergence of Thuja was limited by litter in the deciduous forest but not at the cliff edge. Herbivory restricted recruitment of Acer more at the cliff edge than in the deciduous forest. -from Authors

dc:title: Biological Flora of the British Isles. Heracleum sphondylium L.
dc:creator: Sheppard A.W.
dc:description: No. 171 in the series features hogweed, a morphologically variable perennial found in all vice-counties of the British Isles. The plant is described, mentioning geographic variants and subspecies. The article then gives comprehensive descriptions of the following aspects: geographical and altitudinal distribution; habitat; communities (including a table summarizing data from the National Vegetation Classification for communities and subcommunities containing H. sphondylium); response to biotic factors; gregariousness, performance in various habitats, and effect of frost and drought; morphology, mycorrhiza, reproduction, physiological and biochemical data, phenology, etc; flora biology, hybrids, seeds, germination, etc.; animal feeders, parasites and diseases; and history. -J.W.Cooper

dc:title: Ecological genetic variation in seedbanks. II. Phenotypic and genetic differences between young and old subpopulations of Luzula parviflora
dc:creator: Bennington C.
dc:description: Genetic change over time in a population of Luzula parviflora was investigated by germinating seeds from a seed bank that was time-stratified beneath a solifluction lobe at Eagle Creek, Alaska. The oldest subpopulation was c150 yr old. When plants which germinated directly from the seed bank were grown in a common environment, subpopulations differed for nearly all variables measured. Young subpopulation plants were initially smaller than plants from other subpopulations, but because of significantly higher growth rates, many of the differences in size were not significant by the final (seventh) census. Differences which may have been due to maternal/environmental effects were minimized by clonally replicating all genotypes from young and old buried subpopulations. Each genotype was subjected to three nutrient levels. For morphological traits that differed, the young subpopulation tended to be larger than either the plants from the active seed bank or the old subpopulation. In the same comparisons, growth rates of plants from the young subpopulation tended to be less. There was also tendency for the young subpopulation to respond differently to nutrient treatments. Persistent phenotypic differences demonstrate genetic differences between different-aged subpopulations, possibly the result of selection or drift acting over c150 yr. (See also 92L/07922 and 07966). -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of the timing of multiple grazings by geese on net above- ground primary production of swards of Puccinellia phryganodes
dc:creator: Hik D.
dc:description: Examined the effects of the frequency and timing of multiple grazings (including faecal input) by captive goslings of the lesser snow goose Chen caerulescens caerulescens on net above-ground primary production (NAPP) and shoot nitrogen content of swards of Puccinellia phryganodes. The effects of clipping and addition of nitrogen on the growth in pots of individual tillers of this grass were also investigated. The clipping of leaves per se had a detrimental effect on shoot growth and NAPP. Addition of nutrients ameliorated the adverse effects of clipping on shoot growth. Plants which received nutrients, but whose leaves were not clipped, produced the highest amount of above-ground biomass. Plots grazed on three occasions at intervals of 12 days from late June to early August during the period of rapid growth of above-ground biomass most closely mimicked the foraging behaviour of the wild geese. Departure of wild geese in early August may be necessary if swards are to recover from the effects of defoliation. During the summer of 1987, forage quality (N content) and NAPP together were highest in plots grazed on three occasions at intervals of 12 days - the treatment closest to the foraging pattern of wild birds. In July of the following summer shoot N content did not differ among the exclosed plots, irrespective of the treatment in 1987, and all values were lower than that for shoots from adjacent swards which were grazed and fertilized by wild geese. NAPP and the nutritional quality of forage are dependent on faecal input, number and timing of the grazing events and the phenology of plant growth. -from Authors

dc:title: Succession from heather moorland to birch woodland. III. Seed availability, germination and early growth
dc:creator: Hester A.J.
dc:description: At Glenlivet (Grampian) and Speyside (Highland Region), Scotland, numbers of seeds of Calluna vulgaris in the seed rain decreased rapidly with increasing age of birch Betula stands. Large numbers of Calluna seeds were found, however, in soil beneath all ages of birch as well as the open moor, illustrating the longevity of seeds of this species. Large numbers of Deschampsia flexuosa seeds arrived in the seed rain but very few germinated from the soil, indicating dependence on immediate seed regeneration, unlike Agrostis capillaris which had large, persistent soil seed stores. Presence of seeds of Anthoxanthum odoratum, Agrostis capillaris and Rumex acetosella in seed rain and soil seed stores showed that the absence of these species from open moorland and young birch was not due to unavailability of propagules. Germination was apparently not affected by stand age, with the exception of A. capillaris and Cerastium holosteoides which showed reduced germination on the open moor. Early growth of most species was faster, however, beneath the birch than on the open moor and improved beneath increasing ages of birch. Natural regrowth of vegetation in the cleared plots was faster beneath the older birch than the young birch or the open moor. -from Authors

dc:title: Soil-surface characteristics, microtopography and proximity to mature shrubs: effects on survival of several cohorts of Atriplex vesicaria seedlings
dc:creator: Eldridge D.
dc:description: There was no consistency between cohorts as to which microsites supported greatest survival. -from Authors

dc:title: Direct and delayed costs of reproduction in Aesculus californica
dc:creator: Newell E.
dc:description: In this shoot-level analysis, direct costs were measured as the total non-structural carbohydrate, nitrogen and total dry weight in reproductive tissues. Delayed costs were measured as deleterious effects of reproduction on growth and reproduction in the season following reproduction. Costs of reproduction were unevenly distributed among shoots. Fruit-bearing shoots incurred the greatest direct and indirect costs. Mature fruits were produced on only 42% of flowering shoots following the abortion of >90% of bisexual flowers and young fruits. The dry weight allocated to reproduction on non-bearing shoots was only 12% of the amount allocated on fruit-bearing shoots. Fruit-bearing shoots incurred delayed costs not shared by other branches. In the season following reproduction, bud break on fruit-bearing shoots was significantly later than on non-bearing shoots. The dry weight and leaf area of new growth produced on previously fruiting branches was <1/3 of that produced on non-fruiting branches. Leaf nitrogen concentration was also significantly lower on previously fruiting branches. -from Author

dc:title: Intraspecific comparisons of biomass dynamics in Scirpus americanus and Scirpus maritimus on the Fraser River delta
dc:creator: Karagatzides J.
dc:description: Scirpus americanus plants on the high marsh had greater shoot densities, flowering frequencies, above- and below-ground masses than plants growing on the low marsh. Shoot density of S. maritimus was highest on the low marsh but its flowering frequency, and above- and below-ground masses were greatest on the high marsh. At all sites sampled, vegetative reproductive effort exceeded sexual reproductive effort; within each species, total reproductive effort on the high marsh exceeded that measured on the low marsh. For both species, low-marsh stands had higher shoot growth rates per gram below-ground mass per hour of tidal exposure than high-marsh stands, but shoot mass m-2 was greatest on the high marsh. Enhanced plant mass on the high marsh is associated with larger below-ground reserves, but is ultimately a product of prolonged aerial exposure. Transplant experiments indicated that the high- and low-marsh populations of S. americanus and S. maritimus consist of different genotypes which show similar phenotypes when grown in a common environment. -from Authors

dc:title: The ecology of the strandline annuals Cakile maritima and Salsola kali. I. Environmental factors affecting plant performance
dc:creator: Pakeman R.
dc:description: Large, rapidly growing plants are associated with sand containing macroalgal litter, whereas small stunted plants are found on foredunes above the limit of tidal inundation. Edaphic variables and plant nutrient concentrations were monitored throughout the growing season of 1988 at Harlech, N Wales. Nitrogen was more concentrated in strandline sand and was at much higher concentrations in the leaves of C. maritima and S. kali growing on this sand, compared with foredune sand, especially at the end of the growing season. This difference in growth was probably caused by higher N availability on the strandline, and might have been exacerbated by a N-dependent salt stimulation of growth of strandline established plants and the greater demand on leaf N for the accumulation of nitrogenous solutes in the N-deficient plants on the foredune. A difference in the availability of P between foredune and strandline sand may also have contributed to this difference in growth. (See also 92L/01538). -from Authors

dc:title: Leaf change and fruit production in six neotropical Moraceae species
dc:creator: Milton K.
dc:description: A study was carried out in Panama on Ficus insipida and F. yoponensis (subgenus Pharmacosycea), F. obtusifolia and F. costaricana (subgenus Urostigma), Cecropia insignis and Poulsenia armata. Overall, phenological activities were more pronounced in the drier half of the year, but at least some leaf shed, leaf flush and fruit production took place throughout the year in most species. As a family, as species and, frequently, as individuals, these Moraceae exhibited phenological traits that would tend to make their new leaves and/or fruits available to primary consumers in this forest for much or all of an annual cycle. The reproductive phenology of Ficus species in this study contrasted with that of C. insignis and P. armata in that individuals of the Ficus species could produce massive fruit crops at any time of year. This temporal flexibility with respect to the timing of fruit crops appears to relate, at least in part, to the obligate mutualism of fig trees with wasp pollinators. -from Author

dc:title: Variation between years in pollen and nutrient limitation of fruit- set in Banksia spinulosa
dc:creator: Vaughton G.
dc:description: For Banksia spinulosa var. neoanglica (Proteaceae) in natural sclerophyll forest fruit production differed fourfold among years indicating that the conditions determining fruit-set were variable. Levels of cross-pollination, as estimated by visits of nectarivorous birds to inflorescences, differed threefold. In 1986, when natural levels of fruit-set were high, the number of fruits plant-1 was not increased by adding nutrients or cross-pollen, either separately or together. In 1988, when natural levels of fruit-set were lower than in 1986, fruit production plant-1 increased by 65% and 114% following the separate additions of nutrients and cross-pollen, respectively, and by 298% following the addition of both. In 1989, plants that received additional nutrients in 1988 produced more fruits than did plants that did not receive nutrients. There was no such effect in 1987 following the 1986 experiment. -from Author

dc:title: A comparative study of the population dynamics of five species of Veronica in natural habitats
dc:creator: Boutin C.
dc:description: The population dynamics of three annual species (Veronica arvensis, V. hederifolia, V. persica) and two perennial species (V. serpyllifolia, V. chamaedrys) were compared in six sites in which one or more of the species grew naturally. In some sites where growing plants were absent seeds of three or four of the species were present. The perennials generally contributed less to the buried seed population than the annuals, although some seeds of V. serpyllifolia were present in the soil of all the sites. The species differed in times and rates of germination, The species can be placed in order with respect to their increasing length of life, ability to form adventitious roots, reduced degree of self-pollination and openness of their habitats: V. hederifolia < V. arvensis < V. persica < V. serpyllifolia < V. chamaedrys. -from Authors

dc:title: Genetic differentiation between populations of Plantago lanceolata. I. Local adaption in three contrasting habitats
dc:creator: Van Tienderen P.H.
dc:description: The populations consistently differed in vegetative growth, growth habit, number of seeds when ripe spikes were produced, and onset of flowering at all sites. Plants from an early-mown hayfield flowered earlier than plants from a late-mown hayfield; plants from a pasture population flowered last. Following transplant, seed yield of all alien populations was reduced in relation to the native population by 40-95%. Fitness differences between native and alien populations after taking variation in reproductive traits into account were much higher than differences due to survival in juvenile or adult stage alone. Although the phenotype is highly plastic, genetically determined differences in plant development appear to be maintained and have a great impact on lifetime seed yield. -from Authors

dc:title: Diaspore weight, dispersal, growth form and perenniality of central Australian plants
dc:creator: Jurado E.
dc:description: Diaspore weight and dispersal were measured in 229 plant species of the central Australian arid zone. The frequency distribution of log diaspore sizes was unimodal. The quantity of reserve (embryo plus endosperm) stored in the seed was related to the weight of the dispersal unit. Reserve weight was greater for woody than for herbaceous species. Within each growth form, there was no clear relationship between perenniality and reserve weight. Most graminoids were wind dispersed, and elaiosomes for ant dispersal were more common among the woody species. The number of species with unassisted seeds was low in central Australia compared with other arid communities. -from Authors

dc:title: Contact sampling for the detection of interspecific association: a comparison in two vegetation types
dc:creator: Dale M.
dc:description: A community of saxicolous lichens and the seral communities of primary succession on subalpine moraines were compared with respect to: 1) the treatment of "no-contact' samples, 2) the hypothesis of proportionality (that the probability of a species being a contact neighbour is proportional to its probability of being an initial sample), and 3) the procedure for examining all pairwise associations. The effect of spatial autocorrelation in the lichen data was evaluated, and the analysis was modified to accommodate the possibility of self-contact in the seral communities. In the lichen community, treating uncolonized rock as if it were a species can be justified; while there is significant spatial autocorrelation, it does not have a larger effect on the investigation of species pairs. In the moraine communities, the number of species with significantly many no-contact samples declined from the youngest surface; the interspecific associations among the major plant categories were remarkably consistent through the series of moraines. In both kinds of vegetation, the proportionality hypothesis was rejected. -from Authors

dc:title: Biological Flora of the British Isles: Triglochin maritima L. (Triglochin maritimum L.)
dc:creator: Davy A.J.
dc:description: No 172 in the series reviews this perennial, clonal grass of saline habitats, particularly of coastal salt marshes and grassy palces on rocky shores throughout the UK. Sea arrow-grass is described before examining: geographical and altitudinal distribution; habitat; communities; response to biotic factors; gregariousness; performance in various habitats, and effect of frost and drought; morphology, mycorrhiza, reproduction, chromosomes, and physiological and biochemical data; phenology, floral biology, seed production and dispersal, and germination; animal feeders, plant parasites and diseases; and history. -J.W.Cooper

dc:title: Above-ground crop mass and species richness of the principal types of herbaceous rich-fen vegetation of lowland England and Wales
dc:creator: Wheeler B.D.
dc:description: For 86 examples of rich-fen vegetation, September standing crop (SC) and litter-mass values ranged from 80-2918 g m-2 and 37-2115 g m-2, respectively. The April-September net standing crop increment ranged from 58-2799 g m-2. Communities of highest production were almost always deciduous and had very small April standing crop mass. Most low productivity stands had proportionately large April SC mass, reflecting their winter-green character. Stands with greatest September standing crop usually had small proportions of September, litter, probably because of rapid decomposition. An exception to this was some stands dominanted by Cladium mariscus where large September standing crop and litter mass was combined. Some of these stands had the greatest total crop mass (maximum 5011 g m-2). All crop variables except April SC showed a significant negative relationship with species density (number of spp. 4 m-2) in regressions. April-September SC increment (36%) and September SC (32%) accounted for most variation in species density in single regressions. When "rare species score' (number of rare species 4 m-2) was the dependent variable, similar relationships were found but the crop mass variables generally accounted for rather less of its variation. Samples with large crop mass had particularly few, if any, rare species. -from Authors

dc:title: Resource allocation patterns as a function of clonal morphology: a general model applied to a foraging clonal plant
dc:creator: De Kroon H.
dc:description: A general model relates resource investment in clonal plants in terms of allocation to spacers (rhizomes, stolons), to clonal morphology in terms of spacer length and branching intensity (number of spacers produced per ramet). Based on the branching pattern and biomass accumulation of spacers and ramets (roots and shoots) of a hypothetical clonal plant, equations were derived that relate spacer mass S to ramet mass R. For sufficiently large R, this allocation function was linear. The morphological parameters of the model were modified as a function of patch quality (resource availability). In accordance with characteristic responses of foraging clonal plants, spacer length was decreased and branching intensity increased with increasing patch quality. Simulations show that resource allocation to spacers will be low both at extremely low and at extremely high levels of patch quality, but higher at intermediate qualities. This bell-shaped pattern appeared to be a direct result of the opposite responses of branching intensity and spacer length to patch quality. Results suggest that foraging behaviour in clonal plants produces much more complicated patterns of resource investment than foraging in animals. -from Authors

dc:title: Keystone characteristics of bird-dispersed Ficus in a Malaysian lowland rain forest
dc:creator: Lambert F.
dc:description: At Kuala Lompat, the guild of 29 species of bird-dispersed Ficus exhibited asynchronous fruiting phenology, with no recurrent annual pattern. Fig crops were available in all 36 months of the study, but whilst medium-sized and small-sized figs were always available, crops of large-fruited (mean fig diameter of >20 mm) bird-dispersed Ficus were scarce, with only c16 fruiting events yr-1 km-2 of forest. Seven Ficus species exhibited fruiting patterns which suggested some seasonality, with significantly more fruitings than expected in the period February-April. This period is before the usual major annual community peak in fruiting, at a time when other fruit resources are relatively scarce. Ficus forms a uniquely important group with the subset of plants with bird-eaten fruit because of their numerical abundance, intra-crown synchrony of fruit ripening, relatively short intervals between fruiting, large crop sizes and intra-population fruiting asynchrony. These characteristics, combined with their availability at times when other fruits are scarce, makes Ficus a most important keystone plant resource. For frugivores to be dependent on figs in South-east Asia they need to be wide-ranging. Frugivorous birds with small home ranges may have to rely on keystone plants other than Ficus during some periods of fruit scarcity. -from Authors

dc:title: Microhabitat and diel tissue acidity changes for two sympatric cactus species differing in growth habit
dc:creator: Nobel P.
dc:description: Of two cactus species occurring sympatrically in the NW Sonoran Desert, Echinocereus engelmannii has short stems occurring in tightly packed clumps, whereas Opuntia acanthocarpa has stems that freely branch, producing a taller and more open canopy; the stems of E. engelmannii are also much more spinose, being shaded 62% by spines compared with only 10% for O. acanthocarpa. Because of differences in height, the mean daily wind speed was 2.4-fold higher and the daytime air temperature 5°C lower at the top of O. acanthocarpa than at the top of E. engelmannii; similar root depths for the two species led to similar soil water potentials, CO2 levels and temperatures in the root zone. Nocturnal increases in stem acidity and osmotic pressure in the field were about twice as high for O. acanthocarpa as for E. engelmannii, as was the nocturnal CO2 uptake in the laboratory, consistent with the higher photosynthetic photon flux density on the stem surface of the former species. Root length and the ground area explored by roots per unit shoot area were about three-fold higher for O. acanthocarpa, consistent with a three-fold higher daily transpiration per unit shoot area, than for E. engelmannii. Thus, O. acanthocarpa apparently has distinct advantages over E. engelmannii with respect to water acquisition and net CO2 uptake. -Authors

dc:title: Dormancy, germination and mortality of seeds in a chalk-grassland flora
dc:creator: Pons T.
dc:description: Seeds of 13 herbaceous species from chalk grassland in The Netherlands were buried in their natural habitat. Seed mortality was low, except in Gentianella germanica and Origanum vulgare. In Carlina vulgaris, Leontodon hispidus and Scabiosa columbaria disappearance of seeds was mainly caused by germination in the soil. Freshly harvested seeds of Arenaria serpyllifolia and Linum catharticum had an absolute light requirement for germination which was retained during burial. Burial induced a light requirement for germination in O. vulgare. All species that germinated showed some degree of primary dormancy and seasonal change in secondary dormancy. This was most pronounced in short-lived species. The seasonal change in secondary dormancy of surviving seeds was most evident either from germinability in light (Arenaria, Daucus carota, Linum), in darkness (Carlina, Leontodon, Plantago lanceolata, Scabiosa), or both (Centaurea scabiosa). The response of the seeds to temperature also varied seasonally. The amplitude of seasonal change in dormancy tended to decrease during the 3-yr of burial in some species (Arenaria, Linum, Daucus). Rhinanthus minor and R. alectorolophus seeds only germinated in late winter and were dormant during the remainder of the year. -from Author

dc:title: The ecology and genetics of fitness in forest plants. II. Microspatial heterogeneity of the edaphic environment
dc:creator: Lechowicz M.J.
dc:description: Variation in the physical environment was investigated at scales of 0.1-50 m in the understorey of a Quebec forest, near Montreal, dominated by Acer saccharum and Fagus grandifolia, to determine if the spatial heterogeneity necessary to account for the evolution and maintenance of genetically diverse populations of forest plants exists in this old-growth forest. To characterize spatial heterogeneity in the understorey during the late summer, soil pH and the availability of K+ and NO3- ions in the soil solution were measured. All three edaphic measures are predictably similar up to c2m, but at greater distances the predictability is negligible and the environmental regime is best estimated by the mean for the site as a whole. Results demonstrate environmental variance at scales relevant to seed dispersal and genetic neighbourhood size in understorey herbs such as Impatiens pallida. This spatial pattern of environmental variation may contribute to the maintenance of genetic variation through selection of locally adapted subpopulations. (See also 92L/07956 and 07963). -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological genetic variation in seed banks I. Establishment of a time transect
dc:creator: McGraw J.
dc:description: In cold environments, such as Arctic tundra, buried seeds can potentially persist in the soil for centuries or millennia. The possibility of obtaining time-stratified seed populations from Alaskan tundra was investigated: 1) a deep layer of organic soil was sampled from a vertical profile through accumulating peat in Eriophorum-tussock tundra, and 2) an organic soil buried by the slow, downslope erosional deposition of mineral soil (solifluction) at Eagle Creek was sampled. Both buried organic soils contained viable seeds. In Eriophorum-tussock tundra, only seeds of Carex bigelowii were found at depth. Dating by accelerator mass spectrometry of seed coats showed that they were essentially modern. Several species germinated from the solifluction-buried organic soil, with viable seeds of Luzula parviflora and C. bigelowii being found in greatest numbers and persisting for the longest time. These seeds persisted for at least 197 ± 80 yr, although viable seeds were also found associated with wood fragments 295 ± 75 yr old. The buried seed profile under the solifluction lobe represents a "time transect' two or three centuries long. Because seed coats were dated without killing the emerging seedling, this time transect can be used to make direct ecological genetic comparisons of past and present individuals from a single population. (See also 92L/07965 and 07966). -from Authors

dc:title: Population responses to fire in a tropical savanna grass, Andropogon semiberbis: a matrix model approach
dc:creator: Silva J.
dc:description: The burnt population is capable of increasing rapidly (λ1 = 1.2524, r = 0.2251), whereas the unburnt population is unable to persist (λ1 = 0.2762, r = 1.2886). Most of this difference is due to effects on the growth, survival and reproduction of the smallest two size classes, which are the most important to population growth in both populations. The stable size distributions and reproductive values are similar in the two populations. Both deterministic and stochastic analyses reveal a critical frequency of fire (c0.85) below which this species is unable to maintain itself. This apparent reliance on fire frequency suggests that the spread and evolution of this species had been closely related to human occupation of neotropical savannas. -from Authors

dc:title: Succession from heather moorland to birch woodland. I. Experimental alteration of specific environmental conditions in the field
dc:creator: Hester A.J.
dc:description: The effects of experimental alteration of light intensity, nutrient availability and simultated grazing on plant communities beneath different ages of birch are examined at Glenlivet (Grampian) and Speyside (Highland Region), Scotland. A generalized sequence of changes in species dominance as the birch (Betula pendula and B. pubescens) ages is identified. Calluna vulgaris gradually declines and is replaced by Vaccinium myrtillus as the birch canopy closes. This is subsequently replaced by Deschampsia flexuosa and then Agrostis capillaris as the woodland matures and the canopy opens out. Growth of Calluna was greatly reduced in shaded plots and nutrient addition had no significant compensatory effect. Empetrum nigrum showed similar growth responses. Vaccinium myrtillus and D. flexuosa also grew less well in reduced light but D. flexuosa responded positively to nutrient addition. Clipping reduced the growth of Calluna, E. nigrum, V. myrtillus and D. flexuosa in most plots. Only Galium saxatile showed increased growth after clipping at one site. -from Authors

dc:title: Changes in sex ratio in experimental populations of Rumex acetosella
dc:creator: Escarre J.
dc:description: Sheep's sorrel is a dioecious perennial species which reproduces both by seeds and by adventitious shoots. The progression of the floral sex ratio was monitored for four years in populations grown from seeds. In the first year, sex ratios were balanced, or slightly female biased. In the second year, sex ratios varied quite widely, depending on census date, population and replicate sample within the population. In the third and fourth years, male ramets greatly outnumbered females. Thus in the long term, male ramets showed greater clonal growth, ie recovered better than females following the repeated energetic cost of sexual reproduction. -from Authors

dc:title: Effect of sheep grazing on the demography of Anthyllis vulneraria in southern France
dc:creator: Bastrenta B.
dc:description: Free grazing and controlled grazing compared with no grazing strongly affected seed output but had no effect on the survival of juveniles and vegetative adults. Vegetative plants provide an important population reserve of dormant buds. Grazing diminished fecundity by reducing plant resources; this effect was greater when grazing was unrestricted. Under controlled grazing, the reduction in fecundity was correlated with an increase in the survival of individuals, relative to free grazing and no grazing. The population dynamics of A. vulneraria are more dependant on reproductive characteristics than on factors influencing survival. -from Author

dc:title: Forest and moorland in the south Pennine uplands in the mid- Flandrian period. III. The spread of moorland - local, regional and national
dc:creator: Tallis J.
dc:description: Pollen analyses from basal peat deposits at a range of sites in different topographic situations in the South Pennine uplands are compared with a long radiocarbon-dated pollen diagram from one of the sites, and used to reconstruct the patterns of blanket peat initiation on the moorlands. Three distinct phases of peat initiation in water-collecting situations, followed by subsequent spread to water-shedding situations, are recognized: c9000 BP, 7500-7000 BP; and c5500 BP. Published pollen analyses and radiocarbon dates of basal peat deposits at other upland sites in England and Wales show a similar protracted period of peat initiation (from c9000-1000 BP overall). It is concluded that the replacement of the upland forest and scrub of the early Flandrian period by moorland vegetation occurred in response to a complex of environmental changes, including forest clearance, climatic change and soil deterioration, that varied in their balance and timing from region to region. -from Author

dc:title: Limiting nutrients in acid-mire vegetation: peat and plant analyses and experiments on plant responses to added nutrients
dc:creator: Hayati A.
dc:description: In pot experiments on a wet-heath peat from E Devon, Cirsium dissectum showed a strong positive response to lime but not to CaCl2, and to added P but not to N. Carex echinata responded strongly to lime, N and P. Peat samples were analysed from two lowland wet heaths (Ericion tetralicis), an upland blanket bog (Calluno-Sphagnion papillosi/Oxycocco-Ericion), and three upland poor-fens (Caricion nigrae). Extractable amounts of the major cations were similar at the six sites, with somewhat higher levels of K in the wet heaths, Mg and Na in the blanket bog, Ca in the poor-fens. The wet-heath sites were lowest in extractable NH4-N and P; highest NH4-N values were in the poor-fens. Total P was highest in the poor-fens; total Mn and Al were lowest in the blanket peat. Plant analyses suggested greater availability of Fe and Mn in the wet heath and poor-fen sites, but otherwise did not closely reflect the peat analyses. A nutrient-additional experiment with C. echinata showed that N and P were limiting growth on all sites. N was more strongly limiting on the wet heath peats and P on the blanket bog. Both N and P appeared more freely available in the poor-fen peats. K appeared to be in at least adequate supply in all but the blanket-bog peat. Differences in processes of N supply and uptake in the wet heaths and blanket bog on the one hand, and the poor-fens on the other, are suggested. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological genetic variation in seedbanks. III. Phenotypic and genetic differences between young and old seed populations of Carex bigelowii
dc:creator: Vavrek M.
